title: Can a disease cure another disease? - Quora

response.answer_text: Systemic disease, either genetic or acquired, may prevent or decrease the severity of another disease. These observations have led to important therapeutic advances. The best-known examples are Edward Jenner's use in 1798 of cowpox to prevent smallpox and J.B. Haldane's 1942 observation that erythrocyte disorders such as thalassemia and sickle cell disease modify the severity of malaria. Patients with and carriers of cystic fibrosis may have genetic resistance to tuberculosis and/or secretory diarrhea. The beneficial effects of undernutrition have led to therapeutic diets for seizures, celiac disease, type 2 diabetes, and inflammatory bowel disease. Finasteride for prostatic hypertrophy was developed after the observation that patients with male pseudohermaphrodism resulting from 5-alpha-reductase mutations do not develop prostatic hypertrophy. Rh immunoglobulin for Rh hemolytic disease prevention followed the observation that ABO incompatibility prevented Rh sensitization

I'd like to point out that a lot of genetic disease traits offer protection… Sickle Cell Anemia: If you’re a carrier and have sickle cell traits and not full blown sickle cell you are more resistant to Malaria. Look at the people who are prone to this disease, they always have roots in places where Malaria is prevalent. Cystic Fibrosis: Highly prevalent in Eastern European Jews. Because of the thickened lung secretions, CF traits offer protection against Tuberculosis, a common ailment among Jewish “ghettos”. Kidney Disease and Hypertension: African Americans are plagued with issues with hypertension and kidney disease that tends to respond well to decreased sodium intake. When slaves were brought over in less than ideal conditions, they were at risk of dying from dehydration due to vomiting and diarrhea. Those with super efficient kidneys were the ones to survive and pass on their genes!

Perhaps the most notable example is the so called “malariotherapy”, practiced by Julius Wagner-Jauregg, who was awarded with Nobel price in 1927. Malariotherapy is used to treat tertiary syphilis, via deliberate infection of malaria parasite. Before the advent of penicillin, it was the only means of curing syphilis. Another example is virotherapy for cancers. It was originally identified that some patients experienced remission after viral infections. Examples include a woman who spontaneously recovered from cervical cancer after receiving rabies vaccine (a live vaccine), and several leukemia patients who recovered after flu or measles infection. Since then there're some practices of treating cancers by deliberate infection of viruses (e.g. measles, mumps), but most of them yielded little efficacy. The field of oncolytic virotherapy experienced a renaissance in 1990s, when reverse genetics was developed. Reverse genetics enables direct manipulation of viral genomes, which makes viruses safer and more effective. The first oncolytic virotherapy, Imlygic was approved in 2015, and many others are under development. Notable examples include PVSRIPO and Toca 511 for glioblastoma(both of which won the BTD) and JX594 for hepatocellular carcinoma.

It had happened. Syphilis vs Malaria. During the time of colonisation of Africa. Before antibiotics. Colonial soldiers suffering from Syphilis. Found that they were cured after surviving malaria. The reason was that the temperature at which the Treponema pallidum which causes syphilis can survive, is in a very narrow range. Very close to human temperature. It could not withstand the body temperature of up to 40-42 degree Celsius that can occur during a fever attack. So if they survived the malaria attack, they got cured from Syphilis.

An opossum, for example, is rarely diagnosed with the disease due to lower body temperature that does not allow the virus to survive.

Edward Jenner is considered the father of immunology. He developed the first vaccine in modern medicine. He used cowpox to fight (inoculate) against smallpox after he noticed milk maids who contracted cowpox would be protected against smallpox. Today we know that’s because cowpox and smallpox are similar enough where antibodies developed to cowpox are cross protective against smallpox as well. Unfortunately, the medical establishment in Jenner’s time did not believe him, and so he had to fund his own work with his own money and resources for what he deemed the good of humanity. A few days before Jenner passed away, he said: “"I am not surprised that men are not grateful to me; but I wonder that they are not grateful to God for the good which he has made me the instrument of conveying to my fellow creatures”.

Yeah, it could happen theoretically. Because many diseases are caused by microbes and one kind of microbes could kill other kind (which simply means one disease can cure other disease). But there are lot of things involved. Let me explain. First of all the microbes which enter your body need energy to survive and the source is your body. When it comes to the battle between two kind of microbes, they need more energy & nutrients to fight, survive and multiply which means you are being destroyed. And above all which one survives will rule your body.

It depends… Some factors of a disease my lead to you doing things that may lessen or cure another disease. Not something you really need to think about. Better to check up with a doctor or two if you need a second opinion.
